text:
e="preserve">"Weep Not, Child" is a novel written by the Kenyan author Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o. It is his first novel and was published in 1964 under the names James Ngugi. It was the first English novel published by an East African.
"Weep Not, Child" deals with British colonialism and the Mau Mau Uprising.
Story.
Njoroge is a young Kenyan boy. He is the first one in his family to go to school. His family lives on land owned by Jacobo, an African who became rich by making deals with white settlers (specifically Mr. Howlands).
Everyone is focused on the trial of Jomo Kenyatta. A lot of black people think he will help Kenya become independent. But Kenyatta loses and goes to jail. This leads to more people protesting and more suppression of the black population.
Jacobo and Mr. Howlands fight against the Mau Mau.
Njoroge tries to kill himself. However, his mothers find him before he can succeed. He is disappointed and ashamed of being a coward.
Themes.
"Weep Not, Child" talks about Kikuyu stories and African nationalism. It also explores the negative effects of colonialism and imperialism.
Jomo Kenyatta, who was the first prime minister of Kenya, is portrayed as a savior of the nation in the novel.
